notes: Third generation A3 (8V platform, 2013–2020). US market offered sedan and convertible. Available A3 Sportback e-tron plug-in hybrid with 8.8 kWh battery. Diesel models (2.0L TDI) offered 2015–2016 before US diesel recall. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi A3 article, January 2025 revision.

Fourth generation A4 (B8, 2008–2015). Diesel models (2.0L TDI) offered until US diesel recall. quattro AWD available on select trims. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi A4 article, January 2025 revision.
Fifth generation A4 (B9, 2016–2023). Virtual Cockpit standard. quattro AWD standard on select trims. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi A4 article, January 2025 revision.
First generation A5 (8T, 2007–2016). Diesel models (2.0L TDI) offered briefly before US diesel recall. quattro AWD available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi A5 article, January 2025 revision.
Second generation A5 (F5, 2017–2024). Virtual Cockpit standard. quattro AWD available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi A5 article, January 2025 revision.
Fourth generation A6 (C7, 2011–2018). Diesel models (3.0L TDI) offered until US diesel recall. quattro AWD available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi A6 article, January 2025 revision.
Fourth generation A6 facelift (C7, 2016–2018). Updated MMI infotainment. quattro AWD standard on V6 models. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi A6 article, January 2025 revision.
First generation A7 Sportback (C7, 2010–2018). Diesel models (3.0L TDI) offered until US diesel recall. quattro AWD standard. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi A7 article, January 2025 revision.
Second generation A7 Sportback (C8, 2018–present). 48V mild-hybrid system standard. quattro AWD standard. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi A7 article, January 2025 revision.

Third generation A8 (D4, 2010–2017). Available A8 hybrid with 2.0L TFSI + electric motor. quattro AWD standard. Aluminum Space Frame construction. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi A8 article, January 2025 revision.

Fourth generation A8 (D5, 2017–present). 48V mild-hybrid system standard. Level 3 autonomous driving hardware (not activated in US). quattro AWD standard. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi A8 article, January 2025 revision.
First generation Q3 (8U, 2011–2018). Built on PQ35 platform. quattro AWD standard in US market. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi Q3 article, January 2025 revision.
Second generation Q3 (F3, 2018–present). Built on MQB platform. quattro AWD standard. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi Q3 article, January 2025 revision.

First generation Q5 (8R, 2008–2017). Available Q5 hybrid with 2.0L TFSI + electric motor. Diesel models (3.0L TDI) offered until US diesel recall. quattro AWD standard. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi Q5 article, January 2025 revision.
Second generation Q5 (FY, 2017–present). Built on MLB evo platform. quattro AWD standard. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi Q5 article, January 2025 revision.

First generation Q7 (4L, 2005–2015). Three-row seating. Diesel models (3.0L TDI) offered until US diesel recall. quattro AWD standard. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi Q7 article, January 2025 revision.
Second generation Q7 (4M, 2015–present). Three-row seating. quattro AWD standard. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi Q7 article, January 2025 revision.
First generation Q8 (4M, 2018–present). Coupe SUV variant of Q7. quattro AWD standard. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi Q8 article, January 2025 revision.

First generation e-tron (2018–present, renamed Q8 e-tron in 2023). Built on MLB evo platform. 95 kWh battery (net 83.6 kWh usable). High-voltage 400V architecture with 150 kW DC fast charging. Requires EV-certified technicians. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi e-tron article, January 2025 revision.
Third generation TT (8S, 2014–2023). Virtual Cockpit standard. Manual transmission on base models. quattro AWD available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi TT article, January 2025 revision.

Second generation R8 (4S, 2015–2023). Mid-engine supercar. Naturally aspirated V10 engine. quattro AWD with rear-biased torque split. Aluminum Space Frame construction. Requires specialized service access for mid-engine layout. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi R8 article, January 2025 revision.
Fourth generation S4 (B8, 2009–2015). Performance variant of A4. quattro AWD standard. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi S4 article, January 2025 revision.
Fifth generation S4 (B9, 2017–present). Performance variant of A4. quattro AWD standard. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi S4 article, January 2025 revision.
First generation S5 (8T, 2008–2016). Performance variant of A5. quattro AWD standard. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi S5 article, January 2025 revision.
Second generation S5 (F5, 2017–2024). Performance variant of A5. quattro AWD standard. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi S5 article, January 2025 revision.
Fourth generation S6 (C7, 2012–2018). Performance variant of A6. quattro AWD standard. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi S6 article, January 2025 revision.
Fourth generation S6 facelift (C7, 2016–2018). Performance variant of A6. quattro AWD standard. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi S6 article, January 2025 revision.
First generation S7 Sportback (C7, 2012–2018). Performance variant of A7. quattro AWD standard. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi S7 article, January 2025 revision.

Second generation S7 Sportback (C8, 2019–present). 48V mild-hybrid system standard. Performance variant of A7. quattro AWD standard. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi S7 article, January 2025 revision.
Third generation S8 (D4, 2012–2017). Performance variant of A8. quattro AWD standard. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi S8 article, January 2025 revision.
Fourth generation S8 (D5, 2019–present). 48V mild-hybrid system standard. Performance variant of A8. quattro AWD standard. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi S8 article, January 2025 revision.
Second generation SQ5 (FY, 2018–present). Performance variant of Q5. quattro AWD standard. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi SQ5 article, January 2025 revision.

Second generation SQ7 (4M, 2016–present). Diesel variant not sold in US after diesel scandal. Listed for completeness. Performance variant of Q7. Electric supercharger. quattro AWD standard. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi SQ7 article, January 2025 revision.
First generation SQ8 (4M, 2019–present). Performance variant of Q8. quattro AWD standard. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi SQ8 article, January 2025 revision.
Third generation TTS (8S, 2015–2023). Performance variant of TT. quattro AWD standard. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi TT article, January 2025 revision.

Third generation TT RS (8S, 2017–2023). High-performance variant of TT. Legendary 2.5L inline-five turbo engine. quattro AWD standard. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi TT article, January 2025 revision.
First generation RS5 (8T, 2010–2015). High-performance variant of A5. Naturally aspirated V8. quattro AWD standard. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi RS5 article, January 2025 revision.
Second generation RS5 (F5, 2017–present). High-performance variant of A5. quattro AWD standard. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi RS5 article, January 2025 revision.
Third generation RS6 Avant (C7, 2013–2018). Not officially sold in US. High-performance variant of A6 Avant. quattro AWD standard. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi RS6 article, January 2025 revision.
First generation RS7 Sportback (C7, 2013–2018). High-performance variant of A7. quattro AWD standard. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi RS7 article, January 2025 revision.
First generation RS7 Performance (C7, 2016–2018). High-performance variant with increased power. quattro AWD standard. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi RS7 article, January 2025 revision.

Second generation RS7 Sportback (C8, 2019–present). 48V mild-hybrid system standard. High-performance variant of A7. quattro AWD standard. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi RS7 article, January 2025 revision.

First generation RS Q8 (4M, 2019–present). 48V mild-hybrid system standard. High-performance variant of Q8. quattro AWD standard. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi RS Q8 article, January 2025 revision.
